instruction: What kind of spectrum was used to detect copper content in tobacco leaves?
Output: The experiment used laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy (LIBS) to detect copper content in tobacco leaves.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used to to detect copper content in tobacco leaves?
Output: Baseline correction, background normalization, area normalization, and standard normal variate (SNV) normalization were used as spectral feature processing methods to detect copper content in tobacco leaves.

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the calibration performance and how far can this metric go in determining copper content in tobacco leaves?
Output:
The metric chosen to evaluate the calibration performance in this experiment was the coefficient of determination (R-2) and the root mean square error (RMSE). The R-2 value indicates the proportion of the variance in the copper content that can be explained by the calibration model, with a value closer to 1 indicating a better fit. The RMSE value represents the average difference between the predicted and actual copper content values, with a lower value indicating better accuracy.

Based on the provided information, the R-2 value achieved by the extreme learning machine (ELM) model with SNV normalized variables in the spectral region of 324.02 to 325.98 nm was 0.9552. This indicates that approximately 95.52% of the variance in the copper content can be explained by this model. The RMSE value achieved by this model was 4.8416 mg kg(-1) in the testing set, which represents the average difference between the predicted and actual copper content values.

instruction: What machine learning models were used to establish calibration models for detecting copper content in tobacco leaves using laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy (LIBS)?
Output: The machine learning models used to establish calibration models for detecting copper content in tobacco leaves using laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy (LIBS) were partial least squares regression (PLSR) and extreme learning machine (ELM).

instruction: How did the combination of univariate and multivariate methods using LIBS perform in detecting copper content in tobacco leaves compared to traditional methods?
Output: Both univariate and multivariate methods using LIBS performed well in detecting copper content in tobacco leaves, achieving good results compared to traditional methods. The combination of these methods allowed for improved sensitivity and accuracy in quantifying copper content.
